title: Things 3 vs Apple Reminders for Students
meta_description: A student-focused comparison of Things 3 vs Apple Reminders for short-term academic task tracking with low learning time and easy switching.
constraint_lens: You need a task list only for a single term, so any learning curve that doesn’t pay off before exams is wasted effort.

verdict.summary: Apple Reminders wins for students because it works immediately with almost no learning cost. Things 3 is polished, but understanding its structure can take time that doesn’t pay back within a short academic term. When tasks are temporary and deadlines are close, Apple Reminders keeps friction low.
verdict.decision_rule: If learning the app takes longer than the term, Things fails first.

sections.heading: What students need for academic task tracking
sections.content: Students need task tools that help them keep up with assignments and exams right away. The best option supports fast entry and easy checking without committing to a system they won’t use after the term ends.

sections.heading: When Things 3 can still make sense for a student

bullets.point: You enjoy learning a dedicated task app
bullets.why_it_matters: If learning the tool feels motivating, the polish of Things 3 may be worth the upfront time.

bullets.point: You expect to reuse the app beyond school
bullets.why_it_matters: Things 3 pays off over longer periods. Short-term academic use limits that return.

bullets.point: You want more structure than basic lists
bullets.why_it_matters: If projects and scheduled views matter, Things 3 can feel more satisfying than a bare list.

sections.heading: Why Apple Reminders wins for short-term school use

bullets.point: There is almost no learning curve
bullets.why_it_matters: Students can start tracking assignments immediately without onboarding time.

bullets.point: Leaving the tool later has no cost
bullets.why_it_matters: After exams, you can stop using it without feeling invested in a system.

bullets.point: The model matches simple academic tasks
bullets.why_it_matters: Assignments and deadlines fit naturally into plain reminder lists.

sections.heading: How each tool fails under short-term use

items.fails_when: The student spends time learning features instead of focusing on coursework.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Apple Reminders to track assignments with minimal setup.

items.fails_when: The student wants advanced task organization or planning views.
items.what_to_do_instead: Accept Apple Reminders’ simplicity or move complex planning into a separate tool.

sections.heading: Quick rules to decide in 10 seconds
rules: If tasks are only for this term, choose Apple Reminders.
If learning time matters, avoid Things 3.
If switching later is likely, keep it simple.

faqs.a: Often yes, because its benefits usually appear over longer-term use.

faqs.q: Why is Apple Reminders better for short-term tasks?
faqs.a: Because it requires almost no setup or learning to be useful.
Yes, especially if they plan to keep using it after school.

faqs.q: What’s the biggest mistake students make with task apps?
faqs.a: Optimizing for a long-term system when their need is temporary.
